translated: The Mansion on the Plane of the Gods
The Divine Maiden’s Mansion
The Chapter on Mañjiṭṭhaka
The Mansion with a Garland of Ropes
“With your radiant beauty,
you stand there, divine maiden,
shaking your hands and feet,

analyzed: na c casi sup pa vādite
translated: dancing to the sound of a drum.
As you dance,
all over your limbs
divine sounds arise,
pleasing to the ear.
As you dance,
all over your limbs
divine fragrances spread,
fragrant and pleasing.
As you move your body,
braiding your hair,
the sound of it is heard,

analyzed: tūriye pañcaṅgike yathā  vaṭasakā vāta dhutā
translated: like the five-piece orchestra.🔽The leaves, shaken by the wind,
trembling in the wind,
the sound of them is heard,
like the five-piece orchestra.
The garland on your head,
fragrant and pleasing,
its fragrance spreads in all directions,
like a mañjūsaka tree.
You smell that fragrant scent,
and see a form that is not human.
Divine maiden, when asked, please explain,
What was the result of that action?”
“In the past, I was a slave
in Gayā, to a brahmin.
I had little merit and was unlucky,
and I was known as ‘Rope-neck’.
I was reviled, beaten,
and humiliated.
I took a basket and left,
and went to the Udakhadhā.
On the way, I put down the basket,
and went into a thicket of trees.
‘I will die right here,
what is the point of living?’
I made a strong noose,
and tied it to a tree.
Then I looked around,
‘Who has come to the forest?’
There I saw the Buddha,
the sage who is for the welfare of the whole world.
He was sitting at the foot of a tree,

analyzed: jhāyantam akutobhaya  tassā me ahu sa vegaḥ
translated: meditating, fearless in every way.🔽I was overcome with awe,
and my hair stood on end.
‘Who has come to the forest?
Is it a human or a god?’
He was inspiring and inspiring to see,
having come to the forest for peace.
Seeing him, my mind was at ease,
he was not like any I had seen before.
He was one who had controlled his senses, and was devoted to meditation,
with a mind that is not turned outward;
He is the benefit of all the world,
this one will be a Buddha.
Frightening, fearful, hard to approach,
like a lion in his mountain cave;
Difficult to see is this one,
like the flower of the Udumbara tree.
The Realised One, having spoken to me with soft words,

analyzed: ālapitvā tathāgataḥ  rajju mālā iti mā avoca
translated: said to me: “Let go of the rope,”
“Go for refuge to the Realised One.”
Having heard his speech,
clear, meaningful, pure,
smooth, soft, and pleasant,
which removes all grief.

analyzed: kalla cittam ca mam ñatvā  pasannam suddha mānasa
translated: Knowing that my mind was ready,🔽confident, and pure,
the Realised One, the benefit of all the world,
instructed me.

analyzed: idam mā avoca  ayam dukkhassa sambhavaḥ
translated: He said to me: “This is suffering,”🔽“This is the origin of suffering,”
“This is the cessation of suffering,”
“This is the path,” which is straight, and leads to the Deathless.
I, having faith in the one who is compassionate, skilled,
and established in the instruction,
attained the peace that is the Deathless,
the state of Nibbāna that is free from ageing.
I, having attained this,
unwavering in my vision,
through the faith that has grown from the roots,
am the Buddha’s daughter, his mouth-born child.
I enjoy myself, I play,
I rejoice, free from fear.
I wear a divine garland,
I drink sweet honey.
Six thousand musical instruments
wake me up in the morning.
The alarm is loud and frightening,

original: sādhuvādī ca saṁsayo.🔽Pokkharo ca suphasso ca,
analyzed: sādhu vādī ca sa sayo  pokkharo ca suphasso ca
translated: and the praise is also a doubt.🔽The lute, the flute, and the drum,
and the women who play the lute,
Nandā and Sunandā,
Soṇadinnā and Sucimukhī.
Alambusā, Missakesī,
Puṇḍarīkā, and Ati-dāruṇī,
Eṇīphassā, Suphassā,
Subhaddā, and the soft-spoken one.
These and other beautiful women,
who wake me up with sugar lumps,
come to me at the right time
and address me as a goddess.
Come, let’s dance and sing,
come, let’s entertain ourselves.
This is not for those who have not made merit,
but only for those who have made merit.
The sorrowless, delightful, beautiful,
great forest of the Thirty-Three Gods,
is not a pleasure for those who have not made merit,
either here or in the next world.
But the pleasure of those who have made merit,
is both here and in the next world.
For those who desire to be with them,
One should do much good,
For those who have made merit rejoice,
Possessing wealth in heaven.
For the benefit of many,
The Tathāgatas arise;🔽They are worthy of gifts from people,
Fields of merit for the world.
Having made an offering there,

analyzed: sagge modanti dāyakā ati  rajjumālā vimānam
translated: The givers rejoice in heaven.”
The Twelfth Mansion, that of the Rope-makers’ Guild, is finished.🔽The summary:
Mañjiṭṭhā, Pabhassarā, Nāgā,
Alomā, Kañjikadāyikā,
Vihāra, Caturitthambā,
Pītā, Ucchu, Vandanā, and the Rope-makers’ Guild;
This is said to be the chapter.
The fourth chapter is finished.🔽The Book of the Women’s Heavenly Mansions is finished.
